location.name: Moldova
location.activity-description: Harmonize national statistics

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Number of statistical areas assessed towards compliance with international/EU standards in statistics & policy-makers’ needs. 2. Number of methodologies and toolkits (incl. administrative data sources) developed/ revised from the perspective on international/EU requirements in statistics 3. Number of tools focused and actions on “quality of statistical output” developed to comply with European norms and best practices and to build necessary national capacities 4. Number of statistical surveys designed (complying with international/EU requirements) and carried out to respond to policy-making information needs 5. Number of stat.staff whose capacities to collect & produce quality disaggregated data within statistical sample surveys are built, by topics explored, to make more data available for the research and policy development 6. Number of professional development events carried out and/or training materials (curriculum, manuals, guides) for stat.staff implemented 7. Number of user-friendly statistical outputs developed & disseminated, no of areas covered 8. Level of data users’ satisfaction with statistical outputs periodically measured and feedback provided 9. Number of data user capacity building initiatives carried out/institutionalized, topics covered, trainees from Gov., CSOs, media whose statistical literacy strengthened 10. Number of policy documents being assisted with M&E tools (stat.indicators, guidance) to contribute to their efficiency and effectiveness 11. Number of research/analytical papers to analyze less explored topics developed on the basis of available statistics in participatory manner

baseline.comment: 1-4. Moldovan statistical system still suffers from inconsistent methodologies, multiplicity of data sources, fragmented statistical activities in line ministries; the data production systems remains weak and not fully in line with international standards and not meeting data users’ needs. 5-6. There are weak capacities of data providers to comply with actual requirements in the field, inadequate resources and lack of continuous training and capacity building for statisticians. 7-8. Data dissemination covers only core statistical areas and is done through traditional means of communication; most of indicators are not disaggregated by sex, age, and geographical territory; and even existing disaggregated indicators are often not disseminated and are not easily accessible. 9-11. Data users have insufficient skills and capacities to efficiently use statistics for participatory policy-making; Government’s monitoring & evaluation capacities are weak; data/evidence-based analysis is poorly applied to analyze the current situation, develop policies, monitor their implementation and evaluate impact, as well as to assess to what extent Moldova is fulfilling its obligations under economic, social and cultural rights.

target.comment: 1. At least 3 sources of administrative data assessed towards the official statistics’ quality requirements and NUTS (Nomenclature des unités territoriales statistiques) regulation applied to draft options for Moldova’s distribution 2. At least 5 statistical methodologies and 2 toolkits revised to comply with international standards and responding to internal data users' needs 3. Post-Enumeration Survey carried out to measure the quality of Population and Housing Census 4. At least 2 software produced, tested and put in practice for statistical data inputting and processing 5. Capacities of statisticians to produce new data in at least 3 statistical fields built 6. Statisticians offered opportunities of PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT (at least 3 missions) learning from EU/international standards and exchange initiatives 7. RESULTS of gender-sensitive and territorially representative statistical SURVEYS disseminated in at least 3 user-friendly outputs, responding to data users’ needs 8. - Not applicable in 2014 9. KNOWLEDGE and ABILITIES of at least 50 data users, strengthened within at least 2 tailored trainings on evidence-based and justification of new policies 10. Recommendations on improvement of Government M&E activity developed to tackle territorial disparities 11. Not applicable in 2014

actual.comment: 1. Three sources of administrative data (Land Relations Agency and Cadastre, National Office of Social Insurance, Agricultural Information Center) assessed towards the official statistics’ quality requirements; NUTS regulation applied to draft options for Moldova’s statistical regional distribution 2. Five statistical methodologies (ANNUAL STRUCTURAL SURVEY ON ENTERPRISES, DISCHARGE of POLLUTANTS INTO ATMOSPHERE FROM HOUSEHOLDS, TURNOVER INDEX IN INDUSTRY, SEWERAGE, WATER SUPPLY & SANITATION) and stat.2 toolkits developed and 1 revised to ensure territorial perspective and comply with EU/international standards and responding to internal data users' needs 3. Post-Enumeration Survey carried out to measure the quality of Population and Housing Census (with support of UNICEF and UNFPA - parallel funding) 4. Three software produced, tested and put in practice for statistical data inputting and processing (TURNOVER INDEX IN INDUSTRY, SURVEY ON DISCHARGE of POLLUTANTS INTO ATMOSPHERE FROM HOUSEHOLDS, ANNUAL SURVEY ON WAGES and LABOR COST) in territorial perspective 5. TRAINING for the personnel of Territorial Statistical Offices on methodological and data collection aspects in the regions within the WAGE STATISTICS SURVEYS (7 surveys that produce data at the level of rayon and/or region), 6. Statisticians offered opportunities of PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT on new data production (on WAGES AND LABOUR COSTS, TURNOVER INDEX IN INDUSTRY, CONSTRUCTION COSTs INDEX) learning from EU/international standards, Romanian best practices and exchange initiatives 7.1. Results of GENDER-sensitive and TERRITORIALLY representative statistical SURVEYS disseminated via NBS databank, http://statbank.statistica.md/, in the chapter „Gender statistics”, in line with the minimum list of indicators in the gender area, recommended by the UNSC and responding to data users’ needs 7.2. 3 analytical / informative notes based on the territorial statistical data, produced to facilitate users’ understand

target.comment: 1. Comparative analysis of at least 2 statistical surveys undertaken to assess their compliance with EU/international standards and feasibility to measure women’s entrepreneurship 2. At least one statistical methodology and 1 toolkit developed to measure entrepreneurship from gender perspective responding to national policy framework and data users' needs 3. Feasibility analysis of Harmonized Set of Gender Sensitive Development Indicators in the context of Government’s reporting on implementation of National Program on Ensuring Gender Equality and its action plan undertaken; data gaps/difficulties/weaknesses in definitions, sources, processing instruments, quality aspects described to be taken into consideration for drafting of a new National Action Plan 4. Not applicable in 2015 5. Knowledge and capacities of at least 5 statisticians to produce new disaggregated data on measurement of women’s entrepreneurship built 6. At least one event organized for statisticians from the East Europe and Central Asia on presentation of UNECE training toolkit for users of gender statistics (in collaboration with UNECE) 7. Results of gender-sensitive statistical surveys disseminated in at least one user-friendly statistical publication (‘Women & Men’), and one e-application responding to data users’ needs 8. Not applicable in 2014 9. Knowledge and abilities of at least 50 data users (Women NGOs, public authorities), strengthened within at least 2 tailored trainings on the use of gender statistics for advocacy and lobbying, evidence-based monitoring and justification of new policies; and within one national dialogue/consultation among policy-makers and statisticians on localizing of SDGs (Goal 5 and other) 10. National strategy on development of statistical system developed; Recommendations on improvement of Government’s M&E activity developed to tackle gender equality and women’s entrepreneurship 11.1. A series of at least 5 thematic data-based analytical briefs related to the

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Human resource management system of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs developed and operational 2. Information Management System of the Ministry developed and operational. 3. Capacity of the MFAEI in coordination of the public institutions in the process of the negotiation of the Association Agreement with EU and the negotiation team of 75 public servants receives training in negotiation, communication and managerial skills. 4 .Ministry has a Communication Strategy in place that is regularly updated and implemented. 5. Number of the EU Directives transposed into national legislation.

baseline.comment: 1. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs and European Integration (MFAEI) is in the process of the reform. In 2006 a government-wide functional review was done that had not covered the MFAEI, and it was not included into the Central Public Administration Reform process. A capacity needs analysis revealed that MFAEI staff require trainings on strategic planning, budgetary processes, project management and other functional competencies 2. There are inefficient internal management systems and processes facilitating the documents flow. 3. At least 12 public administration institutions involved in negotiation of the Association Agreement with EU and the negotiation team (75 public servants) require strengthened capacities with regards to the negotiation, communication and managerial skills. 4. At the beginning of 2008 the MFAEI was issuing rarely a press-release (1-2 times a year), the web-site was outdated and static, and only 10 embassies had websites. 5. Legal harmonization to the EU norms and standards of the Moldovan legislation started.

target.comment: 1. Human Resources management system at the MFAEI strengthened through aligning HR Regulations with the new Law on Diplomatic Service and EU best practices in the area and by putting in place an electronic recruitment evaluation system. 2. Modernization of the MFAEI information management system continued through maintenance, upgrade and development and the system is handed over to the Mynistry. 3. MFAEI effectively implements the Association Agreement negotiation coordinating function through regular inter-agency AA implementation coordination meetings. Good progress in the negotiation of the Association Agreement with the EU. 4. MFAEI effectively communicates the EU integration Agenda to the public, including through an upgraded Website of the Ministry and functioning websites at all Embassies 5. 5 target sectors receive technical assistance for transposing EU Directives and Regulations into Moldovan legislation.

actual.comment: 1. Achieved. Human Resources Management Regulations aligned with the new Law on Diplomatic Service and EU best practices in the area and an electronic recruitment evaluation system developed and operational. 2. Achieved. Modernized information management system handed over under the full Ministry's ownership. 3. Achieved. MFAEI successfully coordinated the Association Agreement negotiation through regular Inter-agency meetings resulting in signature and ratification of the Association Agreement with the European Union. The National Action Plan for the implementation of the Association Agreement for 2014-2016 developed, consulted with the Civil Society, approved and the implementation started. 50 public employees involved in the negotiation of the Association Agreement strengthened their capacity and skills participating at 40 EU integration-related events abroad. 4. Achieved. MFAEI Communication Strategy updated and steadily implemented raising population’s awareness and managing expectations about EU integration process using a variety of tools, including public forums, TV shows, 6 newspaper supplements and the Ministry web-page information. An unprecedented number of almost 11,000 Moldovans and foreigners received high quality services from the Consular Department’s Call Center. 5. Achieved. 5 target sectors – Agriculture, Food Safety, Transport, Environment and Finance - received support from16 international short-term experts in legal approximation. 45 EU Directives and Regulations had been transposed into the national legislation. Almost 600 public employees have gained knowledge of the provisions and implementation of EU law in thematic workshops.

target.comment: Project Exit Strategy ensures efficient handover of the project results to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and European Integration

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Availability of a Central Electoral Commission’s gender policy and sex disaggregated data in electoral work 2. Level of consideration of such human rights issues as language, national minority and disabled access to electoral processes 3. Level of implementation of the Central Electoral Commission strategic and institutional development plans 4. Percentage of staff having Personal Development Plans 5. Central Electoral Commission’s Research and Policy Unit established and operational; (Number of researches performed) 6. Institutionalized relationships with Parliament, key Government ministries and public bodies 7. Decreased percentage of voters on supplementary lists 8. Electronic voters’ register used at all elections after 2015

target.comment: 1. Central Electoral Commission gender policy adopted and implementation started; 2.Electoral laws and processes compliant with international human rights standards and European data protection and personal privacy policy frameworks 3. Institutional development plan operational 4. 70% of staff have Personal Development Plan; 5. Documentation and Analysis unit operational 6. Formal and ongoing processes of interaction with Government and Parliament 7. Supplementary lists reduced or non-existent 8. State Register of Voters acknowledged by stakeholders and observers as accurate and Electronic Voters’ Register used in the elections.

actual.comment: 1. Achieved. Gender Action Plan approved and operational. “A Guide for Electoral Management Bodies on Promoting Gender Equality and Women’s Participation” developed and approved. 2. Achieved. Electoral system allows for generating gender-disaggregated data on active voters; arrangements in place for an improved access to vote of people with physical and visual disabilities (access ramps, special booths and ballot sleeves). 3. Achieved. 4. Achieved. 70%. 5. Achieved. 6. Partially achieved. Collaboration with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and European Integration and Government’s Bureau for Relations with Diaspora in regards to organization of voting abroad; Long term agreement with the State Enterprise “Registru” signed allowing for data exchange and verification though “importer” tool of the State Automated Information System on Elections. 7. Achieved. No need for supplementary voter lists due to the electronic State Register of Voters used in the elections. 8. Achieved.

target.comment: 1. Provide further support to the implementation of the Gender Action Plan. 2. Sex des-aggregated data on the candidates and elected officials in the local elections of 2015 processed and analyzed. 3. Further capacity development assistance provided. 4. 90% of staff have personal Development Plans. 5. N/a 6. Formal and ongoing processes of interaction with Government and Parliament 7. N/a. 8. Electronic Voters' System's high performance during local elections 2015.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. No. of SMEs benefiting from better business advisory services and joint business development opportunities. 2. Number of cross-river business exchanges 3. No. of new cross-river NGOs partnership projects supported 4. Existence of platforms for discussion and identification of feasible solutions. Number of expert communication/exchange projects initiated.

baseline.comment: 1. Lack of efficient permanent qualitative business advisory and development services for the SMEs in Transnistria region as well as initiatives that would establish contacts between SMEs on both sides of the Nistru River 2. Limited cross-river business exchanges 3. Limited cross-river partnerships and contacts between civil society organizations from the two sides of the River. 4. Limited involvement of the expert communities in the identification of feasible and comprehensive solutions to the Transnistrian problem.

target.comment: Targets 2014 1. About 100 SMEs benefitted from business support services and joint business development opportunities 2. 30 cross-river business exchanges supported 3. At least 25 NGOs cooperative partnerships supported 4. At least three projects involving experts in joint analysis implemented.

actual.comment: 1. Target completed and exceeded: More than 120 SMEs benefited from business and export promotion support services. 2. Target completed - at least 30 cross-river business exchanges supported during joint participation of companies from both banks in international fairs and exhibitions, export promotion training and networking events. A network of young entrepreneurs created, within the job opportunities through business support for youth sub-project, is a platform enabling the continuation of such exchanges. 3. Target completed and exceeded - 31 NGOs cooperative partnerships supported in 2014, benefiting directly >14,000 people on both banks 4. Target completed and exceeded: Two blueprints elaborated in the fields of economy/trade and social issues/humanitarian aid as a result of a sustained dialogue taking place on the created platforms for communication between experts & civil society representatives from both banks of the Nistru River. More than 300 experts & civil society representatives were involved in 24 trainings during 2014 for more than 300 men and women, representatives of CSOs & Local Communities to support the implementation of cross-river initiatives, organizational and partnership development, communication of achieved results, results-based management, volunteer management, community mobilization, and fundraising. 3 study visits to Cyprus & Sweden carried out researching best practices in post-conflict cooperation and good neighborhood education.

target.comment: Successful finalization of project activities within the implementation time frame.

actual.comment: The project has finalized successfully its activities, by 14 March 2015, end of the implementation time frame.

indicator.description: 1. Number of infrastructure rehabilitation, environmental, social and medical services provision projects implemented, contributing to confidence building between Chisinau and Tiraspol. 2. Number of cross-river exchanges 3. Number of beneficiaries to get better access to basic social and health services. 4. Number of joint environmental projects involving relevant institutions implemented

baseline.comment: 1. Limited existence of infrastructure rehabilitation, environmental and social/medical services projects in the Transnistrian region 2. Weak participation of communities from both banks in joint activities and initiatives 3. Limited access of people from the Transnistrian region and the security zone to quality social and health services. 4. Weak capacity of institutions in the environmental sector to address environmental priorities on both banks.

target.comment: 1. Increased capacity of additional 15 communities in the Security Zone and Transnistrian region to address pressing problems through joint development initiatives. Access to basic social and health services is improved through at least 15 infrastructure projects on both banks. 2. At least 10 cross-river exchanges involving community actors supported 3. About 10 000 beneficiaries benefited from improved services and small infrastructure, enjoying better access to basic social and health services. 4. Four joint environmental projects implemented

actual.comment: 1. Target completed. Under the Community Empowerment component 16 infrastructural projects were in the process of implementation. 15 projects were completed and the remaining one, reconstruction of Health Center in Dubasarii Vechi was additionally selected for implementation and is currently in the process of reconstruction. Thanks to the implemented projects access to basic social and health services was significantly improved in target communities from both banks of the Nistru River. In order to improve the communities’ capacity better address pressing problems a 9 relevant joint training events were carried out. Also the implementing partners has benefited by continuous technical support. In partnership with UN Women additional two Joint Information and Services Bureau (JISB) were established in Criuleni and Rezina districts. The role of JISB is to strengthen the gender related aspect in community development projects implemented in Criuleni and Rezina district. These services aims to support women’s economic empowerment and improve local governance by increasing access of rural women to information and public services in the security zone and the Transnistrian region of the Republic of Moldova and promote collaborative projects at the community level on both banks of Nistru River in the Republic of Moldova. During 2014 over 350 beneficiaries were already assisted by throgh these two services. 2. Target exceeded. At least 16 cross-river exchanges involving community actors were supported. The cross-river exchanges referred to cooperation and exchange of experience in the field of similar solid waste disposal services, solar collectors and health care. 3. The target was significantly exceeded. The number of direct beneficiaries covered by newly renovated infrastructure exceeds 59 100 people, out of which 31940 beneficiaries are women (around 54%). Also, as a result of the implemented activities 24 long term and over 160 temporary jobs were created. 4. The target

target.comment: Successful finalization of project activities within the implementation time frame.

actual.comment: All activities were finalized and accounts closed, by 14 March 2015, end of the implementation time frame.

baseline.comment: 1. Insufficient endowment of perinatal institutions with specialized perinatology equipment. 2. Inadequate treatment conditions within perinatal institutions due to the poor technical situation of premises. 3. Limited access to quality, evidence-based and cost efficient mother and child health care, including perinatal care and immunization in the Transnistrian region of Moldova. 4. Insufficient endowment of Tiraspol Mother and Child Center with critical pediatric equipment. 5. Poor endowment of perinatal and pediatric institutions with emergency assistance equipment.

target.comment: 1. Based on needs assessment procurement of perinatology equipment for three Perinatal Institutions ( Rybnita, Grigoriopol and Slobozia) 2. actual.comment: 1. Target exceeded. Comprehensive assessment in terms of equipment needs for Rybnia, Grigoriopol, Slobozia and Bender Perinatal Institutions done. Procurement of perinatology equipment for Rybnita, Grigoriopol and Slobozia Perinatal Institutions completed. Procurement of some perinatology equipment for Bender Mother and Childe Center was additionally carried out. 2. Target completed. Grant Agreements for the reconstruction of Slobozia and Grigoriopol Perinatal Institutions were signed. Elaboration of technical documentation, bill of quantities and costs estimates for refurbishment of Slobozia and Grigoriopol Perinatal Institutions initiated. 3. n/a 4. Target fully completed. Needs assessment for the procurement of critical pediatric equipment for Tiraspol Medical Center done. Based on assessments results, critical pediatric equipment for Tiraspol Medical Center procured. 5. n/a

target.comment: 1. Based on follow up needs assessment procurement of additional perinatology equipment for Perinatal Center from Bender. 2. Finalize refurbishment for two perinatal institutions from Slobozia and Grigoriopol. 3. At least 2500 direct beneficiaries of Mother and Child Care Centers 4. n/a 5. 1. Based on needs assessment procurement of basic emergency assistance equipment for Perinatal Institutions from TN region.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Number of installed heating systems in public buildings in rural communities 2. Number of leased fuel supply systems 3. MWth installed capacity 4. Number of jobs created 5. Heat energy provided from straw-fired boilers for municipal heating annually 6. Fuel supply capacity

target.comment: 1. 130 heating systems will be completed in public buildings in rural communities. 2. 130 local biomass fuel supply chains will be established. 3. The overall installed capacity of 130 biomass heating systems will be about 30 MWth. 4. About 300 job opportunities will be created in target rural communities. 5. As a result of installation of 130 biomass heating systems, it will be possible to produce energy at the level of 290 TJ. 6.1 Around 7 baling and 2 briquetting/pelleting equipment sets will be leased from reimbursements 6.2 At least 8 meetings and round tables on improvement of the legal framework of biomass fuel market will be organized.

actual.comment: 1. 141 biomass heating systems were installed in public buildings in rural communities 2. 141 local fuel supply chains were established during the implementation of biomass projects 3. A total heat capacity of 30 MWth was achieved within 141 implemented biomass heating systems 4. 363 new jobs were created in the target regions and communities 5. As a result of installation of 141 biomass heating systems, it is possible to produce energy at the level of 30 TJ 6. By the end of 2014, the Energy Efficiency Agency (EEA) completed the procedure for reception of 16 briquetting and pelletizing equipment units, which were put into operation. Also, implementing partner PIU 2KR procured and put into operation a cumulative number of 19 baling, transportation and shredding equipment sets. 7. As a result of round table meetings and discussions, 37 standards on solid biomass fuel were approved. 6 standards were used as resource for developing the technical regulation for solid biomass fuel (non-industrial use).

location.activity-description: Provide improved conditions for vocational training and occupational therapy for the juvenile inmates

location.name: Chisinau
location.activity-description: Provide support to implement in a comprehensive manner a number of strategic interventions in line with the national priorities for the justice sector reform

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. An integrated e-system for the collection of criminal justice data developed and put in use within the Prosecution Service. 2. Number of prison facilities` staff members covering 100% of prison facilities from Moldova trained on torture prevention and combating standards as per UN Committee against Torture 2010 recommendations. 3.1.Proportion of staff members from Goian Prison for Juveniles trained in application of anger management/violence reduction techniques in the daily interaction with inmates. 3.2. Vocational training workshop established at Goian Prison for Juveniles and equipped with basic instruments and tools to carry out vocational training activities.

baseline.comment: 1. Divergent criminal justice statistics due to inefficient data collection mechanism. 2. UN Committee against Torture 2010 recommendations on training of the detention facilities` staff members to prevent and combat torture and other forms of ill-treatment not yet fully implemented. 3.1.Low skills and capacities of personnel from Goian Prison for Juveniles to take over educational/correctional tasks according to the principle of dynamic security: 10% of the staff is well-trained; 50% of the existing personnel have participated in at least one training. 3.2. No conditions for vocational training of inmates at Goian Prison for Juveniles.

target.comment: 1. The integrated e-system for the collection of criminal justice data developed and tested within the Prosecution Service. 2. At least 100 staff members covering 100% of prison facilities from Moldova trained on torture prevention standards. 3.1. Increase the proportion of well-trained Goian Prison for Juveniles staff from 10% to 99% by the end of 2014, and non-violence Correctional/ Cognitive Programs applied to 70% of juvenile prisoners who have this problem until 2014. 3.2. Four rooms for vocational training activities refurbished, basic instruments and tools for the pottery workshop provided.

actual.comment: 1. Achieved: The testing version of the informational system "e-Case" developed and put in use; the beta version of the system presented to a group of 70 prosecutors; an internal Working Group established within the General Prosecutor Office to test and endorse the system`s features as compared to the internal business processes and applicable procedures. 2. Achieved: 100% of prison facilities and prison administration staff (89 men and 11 women) c trained on standards of torture and ill-treatment prevention in prison environment. 3.1. Partially achieved: Professional capacities of 80% of Goian Prison staff (including 100% of staff members recruited during the first 6 months of 2014) improved, coaching provided; 56% (14 out of 25) of inmates serving the sentence in 2014 were involved in correctional cognitive programs, meant to change their attitudes towards using violence in solving a conflict situation and prepare them for the reintegration into society following release from prison. 3.2. Achieved: Eight rooms and auxiliary spaces renovated to serve for vocational training and additional activities; equipment (including one kiln, two pottery wheels and other accessories) for the pottery workshop provided.

target.comment: 1. An objective e-system for the collection of criminal justice data functional and in use. 2. N/A: Achieved in 2014 3.1. Correctional cognitive programs are applied to 70% of juvenile inmates from the Goian Prison, who have had this problem until 2014. 3.2. Specialized furniture, accessories and consumables are provided for shoemaker workshop.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Number of communities and hectares of pastures managed according to the pasture management plans. 2. Number of hectares of community forests managed according to the forest management plans. 3. Number of hectares of pastures land restored using economic valuable species. 4. Number of hectares of community degraded lands afforested using native species as lead species (oak, linden, field maple, ash, elm, cherry, poplar, willow). 5. Monitoring system in place consisting of a) ecological integrity of the grassland ecosystem (richness and density of indicator species populations, such as indicator species (Festuca valesiaca, Bothriochloa ischaemum, Stipa capillata, Poa bulbosa, Poa angustifolia, Artemisia austriaca)). b) volume of biomass growth for forest ecosystems c) carbon dividends 6. Number of people involved in the capacity building and awareness activities at the national, regional and local levels. Increased level of understanding about sustainable grassland, forest management and climate change risks.

baseline.comment: 1. No communities (0 ha) with pasture management plans in place. 2. 0 ha of community forests with management plans 3. Degraded pasture on the most of the park territory 4. No degraded lands afforested on the park territory. 5. No monitoring system in place. 6. Insufficient trainings and awareness in sustainable grassland and forest management

target.comment: 1. Comprehensive pasture inventory of the remaining 5,397.92 ha conducive to formulation of the pasture management plans is completed and a Grazing Monitoring System is in place. 2. Forest inventorying conducive to formulation of forest management plan completed on 1,392 ha of community forests 3. The most suitable pasture plots identified and implementation of pasture restoration projects started 4. Soil preparation for 110 ha completed and plantation of 150 ha of degraded lands from seeds or seedlings ensured. 5.1 Carbon monitoring and assessment of afforested degraded lands conducted (indicators: above-ground tree vegetation, carbon stocks of dead wood, litter biomass, biodiversity monitoring). 5.2 Monitoring activities on the restored pasture lands conducted indicators: soil carbon, biomass of herbaceous vegetation.

actual.comment: 1. All 5,890 ha of pasture lands had been inventoried contributing to development of 18 well-balanced, comprehensive and cost-efficient pasture management plans and the draft version of the Grazing Monitoring System is available enabling timely monitoring of the pastures condition and taking of the prompt response measures. 2. All 1,392 hectares of community forests were inventoried in the field, vegetation described and data processed, allowing for development of the forest management plans . 3. Criteria for selection of pasture lands proposed for restoration had been developed, consulted and approved by the project board members and pasture restoration grants allocated on time 4.1 Soil preparation was completed for 120 hectares of degraded lands and plantation on 130 hectares of degraded lands from seeds and seedlings ensured. 5.1 The initial data obtained from field measurements of carbon monitoring of degraded lands performed in 2013 proposed for afforestation was analysed in laboratory and included in the developed computer based Carbon Monitoring Database. 5.2 The initial carbon monitoring and biodiversity assessment was performed on pasture lands proposed for restoration based on demarcated 34 sample plots (19 from slopes and 15 from meadows) contributing to establishment of baseline for carbon from soil and carbon from biomass, as well as biodiversity richness and abundance.

target.comment: 1. 18 pasture management plans for 5890 ha of pasture broadly consulted with pasture owners and users and put in practice 2. Forest management plans provided to beneficiaries and appropriate guidance for their implementation ensured on 1,392 ha 3. Monitoring of pasture restoration grants ensured for their proper and timely implementation on 472 ha of allocated lands. 4. Completion, management, guarding and protection of forest plantations established on 150 ha of degraded lands in order to ensure the 78% overall survival of plantings according to the forestry technical norms for Orhei region. LPA’s participation ensured in plantations guarding and protection. 5. Keep up with the latest carbon monitoring tools, practices at the global and regional level in order to update the developed Carbon Monitoring Database, under the project. 6. A training programme in sustainable grassland and forest management developed and delivered for local communities, farmers, leaders of farmer association and other key groups; exchange of information on successful practices in pasture restoration and management in cooperation with other relevant initiatives ensured at both national and regional level

location.name: Chisinau
location.activity-description: Institutional and functional capacities of the National Integrity Commission of Republic of Moldova strengthened

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. National Integrity Commission Strategic Development Plan developed and approved 2. Draft legislation for the reform of the National Integrity Commission developed through a public consultation process. 3. National Integrity Commission Internal Rules of Procedure in place; Number of analytical papers developed; Number of Guides on the conflict of interest developed; Number of capacity development events for the National Integrity Commission; Number of press-conferences and public events organized 4. Number of training programmes on the Conflict of interest developed; Memorandum of Cooperation with the Romanian NIA developed and agreed

baseline.comment: 1. National Integrity Commission Strategic Development Plan non-existent. 2. Relevant legislative framework contains contradictory norms and gaps and needs improvement 3. Insufficient institutional and staff capacity of the National Integrity Commission 4. Partnerships with other institutions at the initial stage

target.comment: 1. National Integrity Commission Strategic Development Plan development started 2. Provide support in the development of the legal framework relevant to the activity of the National Integrity Commission 3. Training Plan for staff of the National Integrity Commission developed and agreed 4. Start preparations for the development of the training programmes on the Conflict of interest.

actual.comment: 1. Achieved. The national consultant for the elaboration of the National Integrity Commission Institutional Development Strategy and the Action Plan selected. The methodology for the elaboration of the Strategic Development Plan developed and the first draft of the Plan elaborated; 2. Achieved. 3 draft laws elaborated (Law in declaration of assets and public interest; Law on the National Integrity Center and Law on the amendment of certain legislative acts) and publicly debated. 3. Achieved. 15 National Integrity Commission staff trained on legal drafting skills. 4. Achieved. Consultations with the Academy of Public Administration and the National Institute of Justice on the training programmes on the Conflict of Interest started.

target.comment: 1. National Integrity Commission Strategic Development Plan elaborated in a participative manner and approved 2. Public consultations on the draft Laws with a view to the National Integrity Commission conducted; 3. National Integrity Commission Internal Rules of Procedure developed and approved; At least 2 analytical papers and Guides on the conflict of interest developed; At least 4 capacity development events organised; Capacity in media relations strengthened 4. 2 training programmes on the Conflict of interest for the Academy of Public Administration and the National Institute of Justice developed; Cooperation with peer institutions abroad established.

actual.comment: 1. Achieved. 2. Achieved. International Conference and 2 workshops on the National Integrity Commission reform supported. 3. Achieved. Rules of Procedure developed and approved; 18 staff of the National Integrity Commission developed capacities for on-going training of the collectors of declarations on assets and personal interests of public offices holders through training of trainers; 4 analytical papers and Guides developed; 15 staff and management trained on the advocacy techniques; 8 staff exposed to the European best practice in the area of integrity in civil service through the participation in 3 study visits; 4 staff implemented short-term internship at the Romanian National Integrity Agency; Public Relations Officer trained in media relations 4. 2 training programmes on the Conflict of interest for the Academy of Public Administration and the National Institute of Justice developed; Memorandum of Cooperation with the Romanian National Integrity Agency developed and agreed; Memorandum of Cooperation with the Slovenian Commission of Prevention of Corruption signed.
